sen.j: 進藤 長之 （しんどう ながゆき、寛文6年（1666年） - 享保12年1月5日 (旧暦)（1727年1月26日））は近衛家諸大夫をつとめた青侍(皇族や公家に仕える武士)。
sen.e: Nagayuki SHINDO (1666 to January 26, 1727) was a blue samurai (warrior who serves for a royal family or a court noble) who served for the KONOE family as a Fifth Rank Retainer.

Nagayuki SHINDO (1666 to January 26, 1727) was an aozamurai (literally meaning "blue samurai," a fifth-rank warrior who serves for a royal family or a court noble) who served for the Konoe family as Shodaibu (fourth and fifth-rank officials).
sen.cmt: blue samuraiは一般的な英語表現ではありません。説明を加えました。また「諸大夫」の説明は用語集を参照しました。
sen.e: Nagayuki SHINDO (1666 to January 26, 1727) was an aozamurai (literally meaning "blue samurai," a fifth-rank warrior who serves for a royal family or a court noble) who served for the Konoe family as Shodaibu (fourth and fifth-rank officials).

sen.j: 官位は正四位下刑部大輔。
sen.e: His official rank was Senior Fourth Rank Officer, Ministry of Punishment.
His official rank was Shoshiinoge (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) Gyobu no taifu (Senior Assistant Minister of Justice).
sen.cmt: 官名表記は用語統一リストおよび用語集を参照しました。
sen.e: His official rank was Shoshiinoge (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) Gyobu no taifu (Senior Assistant Minister of Justice).

sen.j: 一族に赤穂藩士の進藤俊式がおり、山科在留中に大石良雄とも関係を持ったという。
sen.e: It is said that, among his clan were the Akaho feudal soldier Toshimoto SHINDO, and he was on good terms with Yoshio OISHI while he was staying in Yamashina.
It is said that, among his clan was Toshimoto SHINDO, a feudal retainer of the Ako clan, and he was on good terms with Yoshio OISHI while he was staying in Yamashina.
sen.cmt: 主語は単数名詞「新藤」なので動詞はwasでなければなりません。
sen.e: It is said that, among his clan was Toshimoto SHINDO, a feudal retainer of the Ako clan, and he was on good terms with Yoshio OISHI while he was staying in Yamashina.

sen.j: 青侍の進藤長昌(輪王寺宮守澄法親王の家臣)の次男として誕生。
sen.e: He was born as the second son of the blue samurai Nagamasa SHINDO (vassal of the imperial prince Shuchoho in Rinno-ji Temple).
He was born as the second son of an aozamurai Nagamasa SHINDO, a vassal of the imperial prince Shuchoho in Rinno-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 青侍は前にaozamuraiと訳出して説明も加えてあるので、今回はaozamuraiとのみ表記します。
sen.e: He was born as the second son of an aozamurai Nagamasa SHINDO, a vassal of the imperial prince Shuchoho in Rinno-ji Temple.

sen.j: 父長昌の母は大石良勝(良雄の曽祖父)の娘。
sen.e: The mother of his father Nagamasa was a daughter of Yoshikatu OISHI (Yoshio's great-grandparent).
The mother of his father Nagamasa was a daughter of Yoshikatu OISHI (Yoshio's great-grandfather).
The mother of his father Nagamasa was a daughter of Yoshikatu OISHI (Yoshio's great-grandfather).

sen.j: 長昌の跡は長男の進藤泰通が継いだため、長之は親戚で近衛家家臣の進藤長房の養子に入った。
sen.e: Because the eldest son Yasumichi SHINDO succeeded Nagamasa as the head of the family, Nagayuki became the adopted son of his relative Nagafusa SHINDO, who was a vassal of the KONOE family.
Because the eldest son Yasumichi SHINDO succeeded Nagamasa as the head of the family, Nagayuki became the adopted son of his relative Nagafusa SHINDO, who was a vassal of the Konoe family.
sen.cmt: 家名は頭文字のみ大文字で表記します。
sen.e: Because the eldest son Yasumichi SHINDO succeeded Nagamasa as the head of the family, Nagayuki became the adopted son of his relative Nagafusa SHINDO, who was a vassal of the Konoe family.

sen.j: その後、近衛基煕・近衛家煕・近衛家久の三代にわたって近衛家に仕えた。
sen.e: Thereafter, he served the KONOE family through three generations: Motohiro KONOE, Iehiro KONOE, and Iehisa KONOE.
Thereafter, he served the Konoe family through three generations: Motohiro KONOE, Iehiro KONOE, and Iehisa KONOE.
Thereafter, he served the Konoe family through three generations: Motohiro KONOE, Iehiro KONOE, and Iehisa KONOE.

sen.j: 摂関近衛家の諸大夫であるため天皇よりしばしば官位を下され、
sen.e: Because he was a Fifth Rank Retainer of the KONOE family, he was often given official rank from the emperor.
Because he was a Shodaibu of the Sekkan Konoe family, he was often given official rank from the emperor.
sen.cmt: 「摂関」の訳漏れ。「諸大夫」は前にshodaibuと訳出して説明も加えてあるので、今回はshodaibuとのみ表記します。
sen.e: Because he was a Shodaibu of the Sekkan Konoe family, he was often given official rank from the emperor.

sen.j: 延宝八年(1680年)には正六位下修理大進に叙任し、修理亮任官をへて、元禄14年(1701年)には正五位下刑部大輔に補された。
sen.e: In 1680, he was appointed Senior Sixth Rank Repair Daijin, got promoted to Repair Ryoninkan, and in 1701, he became Senior Fifth Rank Official of the Ministry of Punishment.

In 1680, he was appointed Shorokuinoge (Senior Sixth Rank, Lower Grade) Shurinodaijo (senior secretary responsible for repair), got promoted to Repair Ryoninkan, and in 1701, he became Shogoinoge (Senior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) Gyobu no taifu.
sen.cmt: 官名の表記は用語統一リストを参照しました。
sen.e: In 1680, he was appointed Shorokuinoge (Senior Sixth Rank, Lower Grade) Shurinodaijo (senior secretary responsible for repair), got promoted to Repair Ryoninkan, and in 1701, he became Shogoinoge (Senior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) Gyobu no taifu.

sen.j: また浅野長矩の刃傷のあった同年3月には勅使の柳原資廉、高野保春らにお供して江戸へ下向していた。
sen.e: Moreover, in March of the same year as the bloodshed incident of Naganori ASANO, he went downward to Edo with Sukekado YANAGIWARA and Yasuharu TAKANO, who were messengers of the emperor.
Moreover, in March of the same year as the bloodshed incident of Naganori ASANO, he went downward to Edo with Sukekado YANAGIWARA and Yasuharu TAKANO, who were messengers of the emperor.
Moreover, in March of the same year as the bloodshed incident of Naganori ASANO, he went downward to Edo with Sukekado YANAGIWARA and Yasuharu TAKANO, who were messengers of the emperor.

sen.j: 刃傷の後、京都へ戻った長之は、主の近衛基煕に刃傷の経緯を報告し、さらに近衛から東山天皇に報告された。
sen.e: After the bloodshed incident, Nagayuki, who returned to Kyoto, reported on details of bloodshed to his master Motohiro KONOE, and KONOE then reported to the Higashiyama Emperor.
After the bloodshed incident, Nagayuki, who returned to Kyoto, reported on details of bloodshed to his master Motohiro KONOE, and KONOE then reported to the Higashiyama Emperor.
After the bloodshed incident, Nagayuki, who returned to Kyoto, reported on details of bloodshed to his master Motohiro KONOE, and KONOE then reported to the Higashiyama Emperor.

sen.j: しかし近衛基煕日記を見ると、近衛も天皇もこの事態を喜んでいるような異様な反応を示している。
sen.e: According to "Motohiro KONOE's Diary", both KONOE and the emperor were pleased with this situation with excited reaction.
According to "Motohiro KONOE's Diary," both KONOE and the emperor were pleased with this situation, which seems an abnormal reaction.
sen.cmt: 「異様な反応を示している」の訳文が、英語として意味をなしません。
sen.e: According to "Motohiro KONOE's Diary," both KONOE and the emperor were pleased with this situation, which seems an abnormal reaction.

sen.j: これと何か関係が有るのか、長之は赤穂城開城後に親族の赤穂藩士進藤俊式を近衛家領の山科(進藤長之が管理していた)へ迎え入れた。
sen.e: Perhaps related to this, after the opening of the Akaho Castle, Nagayuki was received the Akaho feudal soldier Toshimoto SHINDO, who was his relative, into Yamashina, which was a territory of the KONOE family and under the management of Nagayuki SHINDO.

Perhaps related to this, after the surrender of the Ako-jo Castle, Nagayuki received his relative Toshimoto SHINDO, a feudal retainer of the Ako clan, into Yamashina, which was a territory of the Konoe family managed by Nagayuki SHINDO.
sen.cmt: この「開城」は「明け渡し」の意です。「赤穂城」の表記が不適切です。長久は「迎え入れた」のですから受動態は不可。
sen.e: Perhaps related to this, after the surrender of the Ako-jo Castle, Nagayuki received his relative Toshimoto SHINDO, a feudal retainer of the Ako clan, into Yamashina, which was a territory of the Konoe family managed by Nagayuki SHINDO.

sen.j: また赤穂藩政の残務処理が終わった後の大石良雄も山科へ入れている。
sen.e: Moreover, he also received Yoshio OISHI into Yamashina, after he had ended the unsettled affairs of the Ako feudal administration.
Moreover, he also received Yoshio OISHI into Yamashina, after he had ended the unsettled affairs of the Ako feudal administration.
Moreover, he also received Yoshio OISHI into Yamashina, after he had ended the unsettled affairs of the Ako feudal administration.

sen.j: しかし大石が山科から江戸に下向したとき、この長之に金の無心をしたが、長之からは断られた。
sen.e: However, anecdote says that, when OISHI was moving downwards to Edo from Yamashina, he begged Nagayuki for money, but Nagayuki refused.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, anecdote says that, when OISHI was moving downwards to Edo from Yamashina, he begged Nagayuki for money, but Nagayuki refused.
However, anecdote says that, when OISHI was moving downwards to Edo from Yamashina, he begged Nagayuki for money, but Nagayuki refused.

sen.j: あとで敵討ちのためだったと知ると、長之は金を貸さなかったことを後悔したという逸話が伝わっておった。
sen.e: If Nagayuki had known that OISHI revenged on him later on because of this, Nagayuki would have regretted about his not lending him money.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Nagayuki later regretted not having lent the money when he knew that OISHI had asked for money for the purpose of avenging his master.
sen.cmt: 英文として意味をなしません。
sen.e: Nagayuki later regretted not having lent the money when he knew that OISHI had asked for money for the purpose of avenging his master.

sen.j: この逸話が事実なら長之は仇討ちについては何も知らなかったことになる。
sen.e: If this anecdote was true, it became that Nagayuki did not know anything about the revenge.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: If this anecdote is true, it means that Nagayuki did not know anything about the revenge.
sen.cmt: 「～になる」を直訳しても意味をなしません。
sen.e: If this anecdote is true, it means that Nagayuki did not know anything about the revenge.

sen.j: 逆に金の無心をする相手ならば、かなり大石に親身に接していた人物だったであろうともいえる。
sen.e: It can be said that, if the other party had not begged money, he would have been a person who kindly received OISHI.
On the contrary, if OISHI could beg Nagayuki for money, Nagayuki must have been quite close to OISHI.
sen.cmt: 直訳では意味をなしません。
sen.e: On the contrary, if OISHI could beg Nagayuki for money, Nagayuki must have been quite close to OISHI.

sen.j: 果たして長之がどの程度関わっていたのかは判らない。
sen.e: After all, it is not well understood to what extent Nagayuki was related to him.
It is unknown to what extent Nagayuki was related to the revenge.
sen.cmt: この「関わっていた」は「仇討ちに」関わっていたの意だと考えられます。
sen.e: It is unknown to what extent Nagayuki was related to the revenge.

sen.j: 元禄16年(1703年)に従四位下。
sen.e: Junior Fourth Rank Lower in 1703.
He was appointed Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) in 1703.
sen.cmt: 官名の表記は用語統一リストを参照しました。
sen.e: He was appointed Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) in 1703.

sen.j: 宝永5年(1708年)に従四位上。
sen.e: Junior Fourth Rank Upper in 1708.
Jushiinojo (Junior Fourth Rank, Upper Grade) in 1708.
sen.cmt: 官名の表記は用語統一リストを参照しました。
sen.e: Jushiinojo (Junior Fourth Rank, Upper Grade) in 1708.

sen.j: さらに享保元年(1716年)には正四位下となる。
sen.e: Senior Fourth Rank Lower in 1716.
Furthermore, Shoshiinoge (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) in 1716.
sen.cmt: 官名の表記は用語統一リストを参照しました。
sen.e: Furthermore, Shoshiinoge (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) in 1716.

sen.j: 享保10年(1725年)に隠居して落飾し、鴨河西涯三本木に移った。
sen.e: He retired from active life in 1725, got his head shaved, and moved to Sambongi near Seigai (West Cliff) of Kamo-gawa River.
He retired in 1725, got his head shaved, and moved to Sambongi near Seigai (West Cliff) of the Kamo-gawa River.
sen.cmt: active lifeが何を指すのか不明です。「川」に冠詞をつけます。
sen.e: He retired in 1725, got his head shaved, and moved to Sambongi near Seigai (West Cliff) of the Kamo-gawa River.

sen.j: 享保12年(1727年)に死去し、浄華院に葬られた。
sen.e: He died in 1727, and was buried in Joke-in Temple.
He died in 1727, and was buried in the Joke-in Temple.
He died in 1727, and was buried in the Joke-in Temple.

sen.j: 法名は云云庵淡水一葉という。
sen.e: The Buddhist name was called Unnunantansuiichiyo (so and so hermitage one leaf on fresh water).
The Buddhist name was Unnunantansuiichiyo (so-and-so hermitage, one leaf on fresh water).
sen.cmt: 法名が「呼ばれていた」わけではないのでcalledは不要です。
sen.e: The Buddhist name was Unnunantansuiichiyo (so-and-so hermitage, one leaf on fresh water).

sen.j: 享年63。
sen.e: Passed away at the age of 63.
Passed away at the age of 63.
Passed away at the age of 63.
